core_idea: The document outlines Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees, including specific provisions for accrual, usage, and carryover, as well as expanded leave rights during public health emergencies like COVID-19. It emphasizes employee eligibility, permissible reasons for leave, employer obligations for notice and recordkeeping, and protections against retaliation. The HFWA replaces prior emergency leave rules and establishes enforcement mechanisms to ensure compliance.
initial_content:
Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.
Employee Eligibility
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.
How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.
Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:
The employee:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee needs to care for a family member who:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:
(i) The employee’s place of business; or
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.
Taking Paid Sick Leave
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.
Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.
Paid Sick Leave at Separation
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.
Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):
An employee’s need to:
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(v) Care for a family member who:
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
Or if:
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
Or to:
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;
Or due to:
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.
Recordkeeping
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.
Anti-Retaliation
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.
Notice to Employees
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.
Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.
***
Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts. If you have questions about the HFWA, including the poster and employee notice requirements, revisions to language in employee handbooks, implementation strategies, or any other workplace issues, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA), which requires employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees with specific provisions for accrual, usage, carryover, and expanded leave rights during public health emergencies.

**Effective Dates and Employer Coverage**  
- Employers with 16 or more employees must provide earned paid sick leave starting January 1, 2021.  
- All employers, regardless of size, must comply starting January 1, 2022.  
- Until December 31, 2020, employers must comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which provides up to 80 hours of COVID-19-related sick leave. The HFWA does not require compliance with the FFCRA’s Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act.

**Employee Eligibility and Accrual**  
- Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire and may use it as soon as it is accrued.  
- Employees earn at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, unless the employer sets a higher limit.  
- Employers may front-load the full amount of paid sick leave at the start of the year to satisfy accrual requirements.  
- Exempt employees working less than 40 hours per week accrue leave based on their normal workweek hours.

**Permissible Reasons for Using Paid Sick Leave**  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for:  
- Their own mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Caring for a family member with a mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Recovering from or addressing issues related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, victim services, counseling, relocation, or legal services.  
- Absences due to public health emergency orders closing the employee’s workplace or their child’s school or place of care.

**Usage and Notice Requirements**  
- Paid sick leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments.  
- Employers may loan paid sick leave to employees who have not yet accrued it.  
- Employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave.  
- Leave requests can be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any employer-accepted means.  
- Employers may adopt reasonable written notice policies for foreseeable leave but cannot deny leave for noncompliance. Employees should provide good faith notice and attempt to schedule leave to minimize business disruption.

**Carryover and Separation**  
- Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the next year, but employers may cap annual usage at 48 hours.  
- Employers are not required to pay out unused sick leave upon separation.  
- If an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate any unused accrued paid sick leave from prior employment.  
- Paid sick leave may be recovered as a remedy for retaliatory personnel actions that prevented its use.

**Paid Sick Leave During Public Health Emergencies**  
- Employees receive a one-time supplemental leave grant during a declared public health emergency (e.g., COVID-19), defined as a bioterrorism act, pandemic influenza, or epidemic with a declared disaster emergency.  
- Supplemental leave must be at least 80 hours for full-time employees or the equivalent of scheduled/average hours for part-time employees.  
- This leave covers:  
  - Self-isolation or care due to diagnosis or symptoms of the communicable illness causing the emergency.  
  - Seeking medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care related to the illness.  
  - Caring for family members who are self-isolating, symptomatic, diagnosed, or seeking preventive care.  
  - Situations where public officials determine the employee or family member’s presence would jeopardize others’ health.  
  - Caring for children or family members when childcare or schools are closed or unavailable due to the emergency.  
  - Employee’s inability to work due to a health condition increasing susceptibility to the illness.  
- Employers may count unused accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave.  
- Documentation cannot be required for this leave, and it may be used up to four weeks after the public health emergency ends.

**Recordkeeping and Enforcement**  
- Employers must retain records for two years documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and used.  
- Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces HFWA compliance and will issue rules on compensation and accrual.  
- Violations may result in compensation to employees and civil fines up to $100 per willful retaliation violation.  
- Employees may file complaints with the Division or pursue civil action after notifying the employer and allowing 14 days for response.

**Anti-Retaliation Protections**  
- The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees for using paid sick leave and provides remedies for adverse actions.

**Notice to Employees**  
- Employers must notify employees in writing of their paid sick leave rights per Division rules.  
- Employers must post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A.  
- Notices and posters must be provided in any language spoken by at least 5% of the workforce.  
- Additional materials will be available for 2021 compliance.

**Termination of Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules**  
- The HELP Rules, which required up to two weeks of paid sick leave at two-thirds pay for COVID-19-related reasons, were terminated on July 14, 2020, the day before the HFWA took effect.  
- The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.

**Employee Handbook Templates**  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA and other workplace regulations, employee handbook templates can be a valuable resource. These templates provide a structured framework that includes essential policies such as paid sick leave provisions, notice requirements, and anti-retaliation protections. Using a well-crafted handbook template helps ensure consistency, legal compliance, and clear communication of employee rights and employer obligations. Employers can obtain these templates through various options, including purchasing from reputable legal or HR service providers, subscribing to online platforms offering customizable handbooks, or accessing free templates provided by government agencies or professional organizations. Selecting a template tailored to Colorado’s specific laws, including the HFWA, can streamline the process of updating or creating employee handbooks and support effective implementation of the Act’s requirements. Additionally, integrating handbook templates into employee onboarding and ongoing communication strategies can enhance understanding and compliance with paid sick leave policies, reducing the risk of misunderstandings or violations.

optimizations.query: new employment laws in colorado 2023 for small businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado enacted several significant employment law changes affecting small businesses, with many taking effect in 2023 and some extending into 2024. Key new laws and amendments include:

1. **Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights (POWR) Act (SB 23-172)** – Effective August 7, 2023, this act revises Colorado’s Anti-Discrimination Act by lowering the standard for unlawful harassment, expanding protected classes to include marital status, and imposing strict requirements on nondisclosure agreements (NDAs) related to discriminatory or unfair employment practices. Employers must now keep detailed records of discrimination complaints for at least five years. Violations of NDA provisions can result in penalties up to $5,000 per violation [2][4][5].

2. **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA) (SB 23-058)** – Effective July 1, 2024, JAFA prohibits employers from asking age-related questions (such as age, date of birth, or school attendance/graduation dates) on initial job applications. Employers may still verify age for bona fide occupational qualifications or legal requirements. The Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) will enforce compliance with fines ranging from $1,000 to $2,500 for repeated violations [2][4][6].

3. **Amendments to the Colorado Equal Pay for Equal Work Act (SB 23-105)** – Effective January 1, 2024, this law expands pay transparency and job posting requirements. Employers must post job opportunities internally and externally with salary ranges, benefits, and application deadlines. After hiring, employers must notify employees about the selected candidate and provide information on how to apply for similar jobs. The statute of limitations for wage discrimination claims is extended from three to six years [4][5][6].

4. **Colorado Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Act** – Payroll contributions began January 1, 2023, with employees eligible for up to 12 weeks of paid family and medical leave starting January 1, 2024. Employers must remit premiums and provide notice to employees about their rights. The program covers leave for bonding with a new child, serious health conditions, military exigencies, and domestic violence safety needs, with wage replacement capped at $1,100 per week [1][3][6][7].

5. **Expanded Paid Sick Leave Uses under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) (SB 23-017)** – Effective August 7, 2023, employees may use accrued paid sick leave for additional reasons such as grieving a family member’s death, attending funerals, handling related legal or financial matters, caring for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or emergencies, and evacuating residences under similar conditions. Employers should update sick leave policies accordingly [4][5][6][11].

6. **Workers’ Compensation Amendments (HB 23-1076)** – Increased medical impairment benefits for mental impairments from 12 to 36 weeks, effective in 2023 [5].

7. **Noncompete and Restrictive Covenant Law Changes** – Enhanced enforcement authority for the Attorney General and new limits on recovering employee education and training expenses, effective August 7, 2024 [6][9].

8. **Minimum Wage Increase** – As of January 1, 2023, Colorado’s minimum wage rose to $13.65 per hour, with tipped employees at $10.63 per hour. Denver’s minimum wage is higher at $17.29 per hour [8].

9. **Recordkeeping and Posting Requirements** – Employers must update labor law posters to reflect new minimum wage rates, paid leave rights, and anti-discrimination protections including marital status as a protected class. They must also maintain records of paid sick leave accrual and usage [10][11].

For small businesses (generally defined as those with 100 or fewer employees), these laws require careful attention to compliance, especially regarding nondiscrimination policies, wage transparency, leave administration, and application procedures. Employers should review and update employee handbooks, job postings, NDAs, and payroll systems to align with these changes. Consulting with employment law counsel is advisable to navigate the evolving legal landscape and mitigate risks such as wage theft claims, discrimination lawsuits, and penalties for noncompliance [1][4][5][9].

In summary, Colorado’s 2023 employment law changes emphasize enhanced employee protections in harassment, discrimination, wage transparency, and leave benefits, while imposing new employer obligations in recordkeeping, nondisclosure agreements, and fair hiring practices. Small businesses must proactively adapt policies and practices to comply and protect both their workforce and their operations [1][2][4][5][6][9].

optimizations.query: new employee legal requirements in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado implemented several significant new legal requirements for employers hiring and managing new employees, with many changes effective as of August 7, 2023, and others starting January 1, 2024, or July 1, 2024. Employers must ensure compliance with these laws to avoid penalties and legal risks.

**Key Legal Requirements for New Employees in Colorado (2023-2024):**

1. **Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights (POWR) Act (SB 23-172) – Effective August 7, 2023**  
   - **Harassment Standard:** The definition of unlawful harassment was lowered from the federal “severe and pervasive” standard to prohibit any unwelcome conduct that is subjectively and objectively offensive based on protected class status, including marital status now added as a protected class. Employers must promptly investigate and remediate complaints to assert affirmative defenses in harassment claims.  
   - **Nondisclosure Agreements (NDAs):** NDAs entered or renewed after August 7, 2023, are void unless they meet strict requirements, including mutual applicability, explicit carve-outs allowing employees to disclose discriminatory practices to certain parties or government agencies, and reasonable liquidated damages provisions. Violations can result in damages, penalties, and attorneys’ fees.  
   - **Recordkeeping:** Employers must maintain a repository of all written or oral complaints of discriminatory or unfair employment practices for at least five years, including details such as dates, parties involved, and complaint substance.  
   - **Disability Discrimination:** Employers may refuse to hire or take adverse action only if no reasonable accommodation can enable the individual to perform essential job functions, aligning with ADA standards.  
   - These provisions apply to all private employers with at least one employee in Colorado [1][2][4].

2. **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (SB 23-105) – Effective January 1, 2024**  
   - Employers must disclose salary ranges and general benefits in all job postings and internal job opportunity notices.  
   - Employers must announce job opportunities to all Colorado employees on the same day before making hiring decisions, excluding “career development” and “career progression” which have specific definitions.  
   - Within 30 days of hiring, employers must disclose to employees who will work with the new hire the selected candidate’s name, former and new job titles, and how employees can express interest in similar jobs.  
   - The statute of limitations for wage discrimination claims based on sex is extended from three to six years.  
   - Employers with fewer than 15 remote employees in Colorado and no physical presence in the state have reduced posting obligations until July 1, 2029 [2][4][8][10].

3. **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA) (SB 23-058) – Effective July 1, 2024**  
   - Prohibits employers from asking applicants to disclose age, date of birth, or school attendance/graduation dates on initial job applications.  
   - Employers may still verify age compliance with bona fide occupational qualifications or legal requirements.  
   - Violations can lead to fines ranging from $1,000 to $2,500 per violation after an initial compliance order from the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) [1][2][4][10].

4. **Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Program – Benefits Begin January 1, 2024**  
   - Employers and employees contribute to a state-run paid family and medical leave program.  
   - Eligible employees can take up to 12 weeks of paid leave for bonding with a new child, caring for family members, their own serious health condition, military family exigencies, or domestic violence-related needs. Pregnancy complications allow up to 16 weeks.  
   - Employers must preserve job protections for employees who have worked at least 180 days.  
   - Employers should update policies, designate contacts for FAMLI communications, and train HR on compliance [3][8][10].

5. **Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) Amendments – Effective August 7, 2023**  
   - Expands reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave to include grieving a family member’s death, attending funerals, handling related legal/financial matters, caring for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or other unexpected events, and evacuating residences under similar conditions.  
   - Employers must allow use of accrued sick leave for these reasons without retaliation or denial for business reasons.  
   - Employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year [2][4][11].

6. **Other Important Employment Law Updates**  
   - Minimum wage increased to $13.65/hour statewide and $17.29/hour in Denver as of January 1, 2023.  
   - Non-compete agreements are strictly limited, with penalties for violations, especially for employees earning below specified salary thresholds.  
   - Employers must comply with Colorado’s anti-discrimination laws, including protections based on sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, and natural hairstyles (CROWN Act).  
   - Employers must verify employment eligibility (I-9) and comply with Colorado’s ban-the-box law prohibiting criminal history questions on initial applications [5][7][9][10].

**Practical Steps for Employers Hiring New Employees in Colorado:**  
- Update job postings to include salary ranges, benefits, and application deadlines per Equal Pay laws.  
- Remove age-related questions from initial applications by July 1, 2024, to comply with JAFA.  
- Review and revise NDAs to meet POWR Act requirements or avoid using them.  
- Establish and maintain a complaint repository for discrimination and harassment claims.  
- Inform new hires about paid sick leave accrual and usage rights under HFWA.  
- Prepare for FAMLI program administration and employee notifications starting in 2024.  
- Train HR and management on new harassment standards and anti-discrimination protections.  
- Ensure compliance with wage and hour laws, including minimum wage and overtime rules.  
- Maintain proper employment verification and documentation, including I-9 and record retention.  
- Review and update employee handbooks, offer letters, and employment contracts to reflect new legal requirements [5][6][11].

In summary, Colorado’s 2023-2024 legal landscape for new employees emphasizes enhanced protections against discrimination and harassment, pay transparency, expanded paid leave rights, and stricter controls on employment agreements. Employers should proactively update policies, training, and documentation to ensure full compliance and mitigate legal risks in their hiring and employment practices [1][2][3][4][5][6][8][10][11].

1. **Complexity of Compliance**: Paid sick leave laws differ widely by state, city, and county, creating a patchwork of regulations that can be challenging for employers, especially those operating in multiple locations. Others impose an annual accrual limit that does not reset within the year, even if leave is used. Employers must understand which model applies in their jurisdiction to manage accruals correctly [7].

3. **Interaction with Other Leave Laws**: Paid sick leave often intersects with other leave regulations such as the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), workers’ compensation, and state-specific leaves. Typically, paid sick leave covers short-term absences and can be used concurrently with or alongside other protected leaves, depending on the employer’s policies and legal requirements [7].

4. **Policy Development Guidance**: SHRM offers tools such as sick leave policy templates to help employers craft compliant policies. Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA), which requires employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees with specific provisions for accrual, usage, carryover, and expanded leave rights during public health emergencies.

**Effective Dates and Employer Coverage**  
- Employers with 16 or more employees must provide earned paid sick leave starting January 1, 2021.  
- All employers, regardless of size, must comply starting January 1, 2022.  
- Until December 31, 2020, employers must comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which provides up to 80 hours of COVID-19-related sick leave. The HFWA does not require compliance with the FFCRA’s Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act.

**Employee Eligibility and Accrual**  
- Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire and may use it as soon as it is accrued.  
- Employees earn at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, unless the employer sets a higher limit.  
- Employers may front-load the full amount of paid sick leave at the start of the year to satisfy accrual requirements.  
- Exempt employees working less than 40 hours per week accrue leave based on their normal workweek hours.

**Permissible Reasons for Using Paid Sick Leave**  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for:  
- Their own mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Caring for a family member with a mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Recovering from or addressing issues related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, victim services, counseling, relocation, or legal services.  
- Absences due to public health emergency orders closing the employee’s workplace or their child’s school or place of care.

**Usage and Notice Requirements**  
- Paid sick leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments.  
- Employers may loan paid sick leave to employees who have not yet accrued it.  
- Employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave.  
- Leave requests can be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any employer-accepted means.  
- Employers may adopt reasonable written notice policies for foreseeable leave but cannot deny leave for noncompliance. Employees should provide good faith notice and attempt to schedule leave to minimize business disruption.

**Carryover and Separation**  
- Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the next year, but employers may cap annual usage at 48 hours.  
- Employers are not required to pay out unused sick leave upon separation.  
- If an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate any unused accrued paid sick leave from prior employment.  
- Paid sick leave may be recovered as a remedy for retaliatory personnel actions that prevented its use.

**Paid Sick Leave During Public Health Emergencies**  
- Employees receive a one-time supplemental leave grant during a declared public health emergency (e.g., COVID-19), defined as a bioterrorism act, pandemic influenza, or epidemic with a declared disaster emergency.  
- Supplemental leave must be at least 80 hours for full-time employees or the equivalent of scheduled/average hours for part-time employees.  
- This leave covers:  
  - Self-isolation or care due to diagnosis or symptoms of the communicable illness causing the emergency.  
  - Seeking medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care related to the illness.  
  - Caring for family members who are self-isolating, symptomatic, diagnosed, or seeking preventive care.  
  - Situations where public officials determine the employee or family member’s presence would jeopardize others’ health.  
  - Caring for children or family members when childcare or schools are closed or unavailable due to the emergency.  
  - Employee’s inability to work due to a health condition increasing susceptibility to the illness.  
- Employers may count unused accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave.  
- Documentation cannot be required for this leave, and it may be used up to four weeks after the public health emergency ends.

**Recordkeeping and Enforcement**  
- Employers must retain records for two years documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and used.  
- Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces HFWA compliance and will issue rules on compensation and accrual.  
- Violations may result in compensation to employees and civil fines up to $100 per willful retaliation violation.  
- Employees may file complaints with the Division or pursue civil action after notifying the employer and allowing 14 days for response.

**Anti-Retaliation Protections**  
- The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees for using paid sick leave and provides remedies for adverse actions.

**Notice to Employees**  
- Employers must notify employees in writing of their paid sick leave rights per Division rules.  
- Employers must post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A.  
- Notices and posters must be provided in any language spoken by at least 5% of the workforce.  
- Additional materials will be available for 2021 compliance.

**Termination of Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules**  
- The HELP Rules, which required up to two weeks of paid sick leave at two-thirds pay for COVID-19-related reasons, were terminated on July 14, 2020, the day before the HFWA took effect.  
- The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.

**Employee Handbook Templates**  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA and other workplace regulations, employee handbook templates can be a valuable resource. These templates provide a structured framework that includes essential policies such as paid sick leave provisions, notice requirements, and anti-retaliation protections. Using a well-crafted handbook template helps ensure consistency, legal compliance, and clear communication of employee rights and employer obligations. Employers can obtain these templates through various options, including purchasing from reputable legal or HR service providers, subscribing to online platforms offering customizable handbooks, or accessing free templates provided by government agencies or professional organizations.

When purchasing employee handbook templates specifically for Colorado businesses, employers should consider vendors that offer customization options to tailor policies to Colorado’s unique legal requirements, including the HFWA. Pricing for these templates varies widely, typically ranging from $100 to $500 for basic versions, with more comprehensive or subscription-based services costing more. Many providers offer add-ons such as regular legal updates, compliance alerts, and consultation services to help implement and maintain handbook policies effectively.

To select the right template, employers should evaluate whether the provider’s materials are regularly updated to reflect changes in Colorado labor laws, include clear guidance on HFWA compliance, and offer user-friendly customization tools. Implementation support, such as onboarding checklists or training materials, can further enhance the effectiveness of the handbook in communicating paid sick leave rights and employer responsibilities.

Integrating handbook templates into employee onboarding and ongoing communication strategies can enhance understanding and compliance with paid sick leave policies, reducing the risk of misunderstandings or violations. Employers are encouraged to review and update their handbooks regularly to ensure continued alignment with HFWA requirements and other applicable laws.

optimizations.query: what are the new worker benefits requirements in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado introduced several significant new worker benefits requirements affecting employers and employees, with many changes taking effect in 2023 and early 2024:

1. **Paid Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Program**  
   Starting January 1, 2024, Colorado began providing paid family and medical leave benefits under the FAMLI program, funded by employer and employee payroll contributions initiated in 2023. Eligible employees can take up to 12 weeks of paid leave per year (up to 16 weeks for pregnancy or childbirth complications) for reasons including bonding with a new child, caring for a family member with a serious health condition, their own serious health condition, military deployment arrangements, or addressing domestic violence and related issues. Job protection applies for employees who have worked at least 180 days with their employer. Employers must notify employees of their rights and handle leave requests according to the program, which is administered by the state, not the employer. Employers should update policies and designate contacts for FAMLI communications [2][4][6][9].

2. **Expanded Paid Sick Leave Uses (SB 23-017)**  
   Effective August 7, 2023, the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) was amended to allow employees to use accrued paid sick leave for additional reasons: grieving or attending funerals for family members, handling financial or legal matters after a family member’s death, caring for a family member whose school or place of care is unexpectedly closed (due to weather, power loss, etc.), and evacuating their residence for similar emergency reasons. Employers must update sick leave policies accordingly and cannot retaliate against employees using leave for these reasons [1][5][11].

3. **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (SB 23-105)**  
   Starting January 1, 2024, Colorado strengthened pay transparency and job posting requirements. Employers must announce all “job opportunities” (defined as current or anticipated vacancies) internally and externally on the same day before making hiring decisions, including posting specific compensation ranges, benefits descriptions, and application deadlines. Employers must also disclose information about selected candidates to employees who will work with them within 30 days of hire, including the candidate’s name, former and new job titles, and how employees can express interest in similar jobs. For positions involving career progression, employers must provide eligible employees with detailed information about progression requirements and terms. Employers with no physical presence in Colorado and fewer than 15 remote employees in the state have limited posting obligations until 2029. The law also extends the statute of limitations for wage discrimination claims from three to six years and mandates the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment to actively investigate and mediate wage complaints [1][4][5][6][8].

4. **Public Employees’ Workplace Protection Act (SB 23-111)**  
   Effective August 7, 2023, this law grants public sector employees new rights to discuss workplace issues, join employee organizations, and participate politically off duty, with protections against employer retaliation. It applies to employees of counties, municipalities, school districts, public colleges, and other public entities [1].

5. **Workers’ Compensation Amendments (HB 23-1076)**  
   In 2023, amendments increased the maximum duration for medical impairment benefits related to mental impairment from 12 to 36 weeks, enhancing benefits for workers with mental health conditions resulting from workplace injuries [1][10].

6. **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA) (SB 23-058)**  
   Beginning July 1, 2024, employers are prohibited from asking job applicants for age-related information on initial applications, including date of birth and education attendance or graduation dates, to reduce age discrimination risks. Employers may still verify age for bona fide occupational qualifications or legal requirements. The Colorado Department of Labor and Employment will enforce this law with fines for violations [1][5][8].

7. **Other Notable Changes**  
   - The Colorado Overtime and Minimum Pay Standards Order was updated effective January 1, 2024, including changes to minimum wage rates and overtime rules, especially for tipped employees [6][7].  
   - The Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights (POWR) Act, effective August 2023, expanded anti-discrimination protections, redefined harassment standards, voided certain nondisclosure agreements, and imposed new recordkeeping requirements on employers [1][5][6].  
   - Employers must provide reasonable accommodations for pregnancy-related conditions (Pregnant Workers Fairness Act) and nursing mothers (PUMP Act) [7].  
   - Employers must update workplace notices and posters to reflect these changes [7].

**Summary:**  
Colorado’s 2023 worker benefits requirements emphasize expanded paid leave rights (both sick leave and family/medical leave), enhanced pay transparency and equal pay enforcement, stronger protections for public employees, and updated workers’ compensation benefits. Employers should review and update their policies, job postings, leave procedures, and compliance practices to align with these laws, many of which take full effect in 2024.

---

**References:**  
[1] BHGR Law Client Alert, Aug 29, 2023  
[2] The Colorado Sun, Dec 2022 - Paid Family Leave and other 2023 changes  
[4] Gibson Dunn Client Alert, Dec 29, 2023 - 2024 Employment Law Changes  
[5] Colorado Employment Law Summary, 2023 Legislative Session  
[6] Employers Council Blog, Dec 2023 - 2023 Laws Summary  
[7] Labor Law Center, Dec 2023 - COMPS and Poster Updates  
[8] Colorado Dental Association, Winter 2025 Employment Law Update  
[9] Center for American Progress, Paid Leave Facts in Colorado  
[10] Babcock Tucker, Workers’ Compensation Benefits in Colorado  
[11] Jackson Lewis, HFWA Paid Sick Leave Summary

optimizations.query: current state laws on mandatory sick leave for businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
As of early 2026, there is no federal law mandating paid sick leave for private employers, but **at least 20 states plus Washington, D.C.** have enacted mandatory paid sick leave laws, each with varying requirements on accrual, usage, covered employers, and qualifying reasons for leave [1][7][10].

### States with Mandatory Paid Sick Leave Laws
Key states requiring paid sick leave include:

- **Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Nebraska, Nevada, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington, and Washington, D.C.** [1][7][10].

- **Alaska** implemented a paid sick leave law effective July 1, 2025, and **Nebraska** followed with a law effective October 1, 2025 [7].

- **Illinois** requires paid leave usable for any reason, effective January 1, 2024, with local ordinances like Chicago’s also in effect [1][6][7].

- Some states, like **Maine** and **Nevada**, have laws requiring paid leave for any reason, not just illness [1].

### Key Features of State Paid Sick Leave Laws

- **Accrual Rates:** Most states require employees to accrue at least 1 hour of paid sick leave per 30 to 40 hours worked. For example, Arizona and Colorado require 1 hour per 30 hours worked [1][7][11].

- **Annual Caps:** Annual usage limits vary, typically ranging from 24 to 72 hours depending on the state and employer size. Arizona caps at 40 hours for large employers, while Colorado caps at 48 hours [1][7][11].

- **Carryover:** Most states require unused sick leave to carry over to the next year, though employers may cap the amount of leave that can be used annually [1][7].

- **Covered Employers and Employees:** Coverage generally applies to all private employers, with some exceptions for very small employers or specific industries. Employee eligibility often includes full-time, part-time, temporary, and seasonal workers [1][7].

- **Qualifying Reasons:** Paid sick leave can be used for the employee’s own illness, preventive care, or to care for family members. Many states also include leave for reasons related to domestic violence, sexual assault, stalking, or public health emergencies [1][7][11].

- **Family Member Definitions:** States vary in defining family members covered, often including biological, adopted, foster, step-relations, domestic partners, and sometimes individuals with a close association equivalent to family [1].

### Recent and Upcoming Changes

- **Connecticut** expanded its paid sick leave law effective January 1, 2026, lowering the employer size threshold and increasing accrual rates [1][7].

- **Alaska** and **Nebraska** introduced new paid sick leave laws in 2025 [7].

- **Missouri** briefly enacted a paid sick leave law in 2024 but repealed it in 2025; advocates are pursuing a constitutional amendment to reinstate it [7].

- **California** expanded leave protections for victims of violence and broadened qualifying reasons for paid sick leave effective January 1, 2026 [9].

- States continue to amend existing laws to broaden employee benefits and expand qualifying reasons for leave [6].

### Compliance Considerations for Employers

- Employers must track accruals accurately, maintain records (often for 2-4 years), and comply with state-specific posting and notice requirements [1][11].

- Policies must reflect state-specific accrual rates, usage caps, carryover rules, and permissible reasons for leave.

- Employers should avoid common compliance mistakes such as requiring doctor’s notes for short absences, applying a uniform policy across states without adjustments, or using sick leave as a disciplinary tool [7].

- Multi-state employers face complex compliance challenges due to the patchwork of laws and local ordinances that may impose stricter requirements than state laws [1][7].

### Example: Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA)

- Requires all employers to provide paid sick leave starting January 1, 2022.

- Employees accrue 1 hour per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year.

- Leave can be used for personal or family illness, domestic violence-related reasons, and public health emergencies.

- Employers may front-load leave or allow accrual.

- Unused leave carries over, but annual usage can be capped.

- Provides anti-retaliation protections and requires employer notices and postings [11].

**In summary**, while there is no federal mandate, a growing number of states require private employers to provide paid sick leave with diverse rules on accrual, usage, and qualifying reasons. Employers must stay informed of state and local laws, especially as new laws take effect and existing laws expand in 2025-2026, to ensure compliance and avoid penalties [1][6][7][9][10][11].

optimizations.query: current trends in worker benefits 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, worker benefits are evolving significantly to address changing employee expectations, economic pressures, and workforce dynamics. Key trends include:

1. **Financial Wellness Programs**: Employers are increasingly integrating financial wellness into benefits, offering resources like budgeting advice, financial literacy education, flexible savings accounts, and student loan repayment assistance to reduce employee financial stress and improve engagement [1][3][4].

2. **Personalization and Lifecycle Benefits**: Benefits are becoming more tailored to individual employee needs and life stages, allowing workers to choose perks that fit their family situation, age, and personal circumstances. This includes lifestyle spending accounts and support for diverse life events such as eldercare, fertility services, and bereavement [3][7].

3. **Mental Health and Holistic Well-being**: Mental health support remains a top priority, with expanded access to counseling, substance use disorder treatment, on-site mental health providers, crisis response, and measurement-based care to improve outcomes. Employers recognize mental health benefits as critical for productivity and retention [5][6][7].

4. **Flexible Work Arrangements**: Remote, hybrid, and flexible scheduling options continue to be highly valued, helping employees balance work and personal life, reduce stress, and increase job satisfaction. Employers also extend flexibility to non-remote roles through adaptable schedules and workplace environment improvements [1][3][7].

5. **Voluntary and Unique Benefits**: To attract and retain talent, companies offer voluntary benefits such as critical illness insurance, pet insurance, identity theft protection, and family-friendly perks like paid parental leave, adoption support, and surrogacy benefits. Unique benefits aligned with company values help differentiate employers in a competitive market [3][6][7].

6. **Consolidation and Simplification of Benefits Tools**: Employers are streamlining benefits administration by consolidating platforms and tools to improve employee utilization and reduce costs, especially important amid rising healthcare expenses [3].

7. **Addressing Cumulative Stress and Burnout**: Recognizing that stress accumulates from both work and personal life, employers are focusing on holistic well-being strategies, including manager training for better communication, workload management, and fostering a supportive culture to prevent burnout and turnover [4].

8. **Compliance with Paid Sick Leave Laws**: In regions like Colorado, employers are adapting to laws such as the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates earned paid sick leave with specific accrual, usage, and anti-retaliation provisions, reflecting a broader trend toward legislated employee protections [11].

Overall, 2023 benefits trends emphasize a holistic, flexible, and personalized approach that supports employees’ financial, mental, and physical well-being while helping employers manage costs and improve retention in a competitive labor market [1][3][4][5][6][7][11].

Independent contractors and certain government employees are exempt. Employees become protected from retaliation after 180 days of continuous employment [2][3][6][7][8][11].

- **Permissible Uses**: Employees may use accrued sick leave for their own or a family member’s mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care. Family members include children (biological, adopted, foster, or stepchildren), spouses or domestic partners, parents, grandparents, grandchildren, and siblings. Leave can also be used for absences related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, counseling, relocation, or legal services. Additionally, leave covers absences due to public health emergency orders closing the employee’s workplace or their child’s school or place of care, as well as new qualifying events such as grieving a family member’s death, caring for family during school closures due to inclement weather or utility loss, and evacuations due to emergencies [1][2][3][6][7][8][11].

- **Public Health Emergency Leave**: During declared public health emergencies (e.g., COVID-19), employees are entitled to supplemental paid sick leave of up to 80 hours (pro-rated for part-time workers). - **Usage and Notice**: Leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments. Employers may require reasonable documentation only for absences of four or more consecutive workdays but cannot require disclosure of specific medical or domestic violence details. Employees must provide notice as soon as practicable for emergencies and follow reasonable notice policies for foreseeable leave, but employers cannot deny leave for failure to comply with notice policies if the employee acted in good faith [2][3][6][7][11].

- **Job Protection and Anti-Retaliation**: Employees are protected from retaliation, discipline, demotion, or termination for using paid sick leave or asserting their rights under the HFWA after 180 days of employment. Employers must reinstate accrued leave if an employee is rehired within six months [2][3][6][7][11].

- **Recordkeeping and Enforcement**: Employers must maintain records of hours worked, sick leave accrued, and used for at least two years. The Colorado Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces compliance, with penalties for violations including back pay, fines, and civil penalties up to $100 per willful retaliation violation. Employees may file complaints or pursue civil action after notifying the employer [2][4][8][11].

- **Notice Requirements**: Employers must provide written notice of paid sick leave rights to employees at hire and post the official Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster in visible locations or electronically for remote workers. In summary, Colorado’s HFWA establishes a comprehensive paid sick leave framework requiring all employers to provide accrued paid sick leave with broad usage rights, job protections, and supplemental leave during public health emergencies. Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for:

- Recovering from or addressing issues related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, victim services, counseling, relocation, or legal services.

**Usage and Notice Requirements**  
- Paid sick leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments.

optimizations.final_answer:
In Colorado, the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) mandates that all employers, regardless of size, provide paid sick leave to their employees starting January 1, 2022. Initially, from January 1, 2021, only employers with 16 or more employees were required to comply, but since 2022, this applies to all employers with one or more employees in Colorado [1][2][3][6][11].

**Key provisions for small businesses include:**

- **Accrual:** Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire, earning at least 1 hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to a maximum of 48 hours per year. Employers may frontload the full 48 hours at the start of the year if they choose [1][3][6][11].

- **Usage:** Employees can use accrued sick leave as it is earned, in increments of at least one hour (unless the employer allows smaller increments). Leave can be used for a broad range of reasons including the employee’s or a family member’s physical or mental illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care. It also covers absences related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, harassment, workplace or school closures during public health emergencies, bereavement, and certain emergency situations like power or utility loss [1][2][3][6][9][11].

- **Family Member Definition:** Family members include those related by blood, marriage, civil union, or adoption; children or persons for whom the employee stands in loco parentis; and persons for whom the employee provides health- or safety-related care [1][2][9][11].

- **Carryover and Caps:** Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the next year, but employers may cap annual usage at 48 hours. Unused leave is not paid out upon separation, but if an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate any unused accrued leave [1][3][6][11].

- **Notice and Documentation:** Employers may require reasonable documentation for absences of four or more consecutive days but cannot require disclosure of specific health or safety details. Employees must provide notice in good faith for foreseeable leave but cannot be denied leave for failure to comply with notice policies [1][2][6][11].

- **Job Protection and Anti-Retaliation:** Employees who have worked for 180 days have job protection when taking paid sick leave. The law prohibits retaliation against employees for using sick leave, and employers must reinstate accrued leave if employees are rehired within six months [3][6][11].

- **Public Health Emergency Leave:** In addition to accrued sick leave, during declared public health emergencies (such as COVID-19), employers must provide supplemental paid sick leave (up to 80 hours for full-time employees) for COVID-related reasons. This leave is available immediately and does not require accrual. Documentation cannot be required for this emergency leave [2][3][6][11].

- **Recordkeeping:** Employers must keep records of hours worked, sick leave accrued, and leave used for at least two years to comply with state law and for enforcement purposes [11].

- **Applicability:** The law covers nearly all employees, including part-time, temporary, and seasonal workers, but excludes independent contractors. Employers with collective bargaining agreements may be exempt if the agreement provides equivalent or more generous paid sick leave [3][6][11].

For small businesses, this means that starting in 2022, even those with fewer than 16 employees must comply fully with the HFWA’s paid sick leave requirements, including accrual, usage, carryover, and public health emergency leave provisions. Employers can satisfy the law by providing a paid time off (PTO) policy that meets or exceeds these requirements [1][3][6][11].

Employers are encouraged to post required notices, maintain proper records, and implement clear policies to ensure compliance and avoid penalties. Legal counsel or compliance tools can assist in navigating these obligations effectively [1][4][6][11].

**Summary:**  
Colorado’s mandatory paid sick leave law requires all employers, including small businesses, to provide paid sick leave accruing at 1 hour per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, usable for a wide range of health and safety reasons, with job protections and anti-retaliation safeguards. Supplemental leave during public health emergencies is also mandated. Employers must maintain records and provide notices to employees to remain compliant [1][2][3][6][9][11].

---

**References:**  
[1] Galvanize Law Group, Healthy Families and Workplace Act overview  
[2] Good Business Colorado, Colorado Paid Sick Leave Law summary  
[3] Snell & Wilmer LLP, Colorado Healthy Families and Workplace Act details  
[6] Colorado Lawyer Magazine, Paid Sick Leave Requirements under HFWA  
[9] Patriot Software, Colorado Paid Sick Leave FAQs  
[11] Comprehensive HFWA summary including accrual, usage, and enforcement

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA), which requires employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees with specific provisions for accrual, usage, carryover, and expanded leave rights during public health emergencies.

**Effective Dates and Employer Coverage**  
- Employers with 16 or more employees must provide earned paid sick leave starting January 1, 2021.  
- All employers, regardless of size, must comply starting January 1, 2022.  
- Until December 31, 2020, employers must comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which provides up to 80 hours of COVID-19-related sick leave. The HFWA does not require compliance with the FFCRA’s Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act.

**Employee Eligibility and Accrual**  
- Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire and may use it as soon as it is accrued.  
- Employees earn at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, unless the employer sets a higher limit.  
- Employers may front-load the full amount of paid sick leave at the start of the year to satisfy accrual requirements.  
- Exempt employees working less than 40 hours per week accrue leave based on their normal workweek hours.

**Permissible Reasons for Using Paid Sick Leave**  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for:  
- Their own mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Caring for a family member with a mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Recovering from or addressing issues related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, victim services, counseling, relocation, or legal services.  
- Absences due to public health emergency orders closing the employee’s workplace or their child’s school or place of care.

**Usage and Notice Requirements**  
- Paid sick leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments.  
- Employers may loan paid sick leave to employees who have not yet accrued it.  
- Employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave.  
- Leave requests can be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any employer-accepted means.  
- Employers may adopt reasonable written notice policies for foreseeable leave but cannot deny leave for noncompliance. Employees should provide good faith notice and attempt to schedule leave to minimize business disruption.

**Carryover and Separation**  
- Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the next year, but employers may cap annual usage at 48 hours.  
- Employers are not required to pay out unused sick leave upon separation.  
- If an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate any unused accrued paid sick leave from prior employment.  
- Paid sick leave may be recovered as a remedy for retaliatory personnel actions that prevented its use.

- Employees receive a one-time supplemental leave grant during a declared public health emergency (e.g., COVID-19), defined as a bioterrorism act, pandemic influenza, or epidemic with a declared disaster emergency.

  - Self-isolation or care due to diagnosis or symptoms of the communicable illness causing the emergency.  
  - Seeking medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care related to the illness.  
  - Caring for family members who are self-isolating, symptomatic, diagnosed, or seeking preventive care.  
  - Situations where public officials determine the employee or family member’s presence would jeopardize others’ health.  
  - Caring for children or family members when childcare or schools are closed or unavailable due to the emergency.  
  - Employee’s inability to work due to a health condition increasing susceptibility to the illness.  
- Employers may count unused accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave.  
- Documentation cannot be required for this leave, and it may be used up to four weeks after the public health emergency ends.

- Employers must retain records for two years documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and used.

- The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees for using paid sick leave and provides remedies for adverse actions.

Colorado’s current labor laws for employee benefits encompass a broad range of protections and entitlements, reflecting the state’s progressive stance on worker rights. Key elements include:

1. **Wage and Hour Laws**:  
   - The minimum wage in Colorado is $14.42 per hour as of 2024, with localities like Denver having higher rates (e.g., $18.29/hour) [2][4].  
   - Overtime pay is required after 50 hours per week in 2024, decreasing to 48 hours in 2025 [2].  
   - Employers must pay all earned wages without impermissible deductions and comply with meal and paid rest break requirements [3].  
   - The Colorado Wage Claim Act was amended effective August 6, 2025, expanding employee protections, increasing penalties for wage violations and misclassification, and enhancing retaliation protections, including for contractors and immigration-status-related claims [1].

2. **Paid Sick Leave (Healthy Families and Workplaces Act - HFWA)**:  
   - Employers with 16+ employees must provide earned paid sick leave starting January 1, 2021; all employers regardless of size must comply from January 1, 2022 [11].  
   - Employees accrue at least 1 hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, usable for personal or family illness, preventive care, domestic abuse recovery, or public health emergencies [11].  
   - Paid sick leave must be provided with anti-retaliation protections, carryover of unused leave up to 48 hours, and recordkeeping requirements [11].  
   - During public health emergencies, supplemental paid leave is granted with specific provisions for COVID-19 and similar events [11].

3. **Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI)**:  
   - Effective January 1, 2024, Colorado offers a state-run paid family and medical leave program providing up to 12 weeks of paid leave for qualifying reasons, plus an additional 4 weeks for pregnancy-related complications [2][4].  
   - Employees receive wage replacement during leave and job protection, with employers responsible for payroll contributions and policy compliance [4][9].

4. **Pay Transparency and Equal Pay**:  
   - Colorado’s Equal Pay for Equal Work Act requires employers to disclose salary ranges and benefits in job postings and prohibits pay discrimination [2][4].  
   - Employers must announce job openings internally and provide career advancement information to employees [2].

5. **Worker Classification and Misclassification Penalties**:  
   - Colorado enforces strict criteria for classifying workers as employees or independent contractors, with significant penalties for willful misclassification starting at $5,000 per violation [1][5][9].  
   - Employers must ensure proper classification to avoid fines and potential bans on state contracting [9].

6. **Additional Protections and Benefits**:  
   - Expanded protections against workplace harassment and retaliation, including broader definitions and increased employer liability [4].  
   - New laws limit restrictive covenants such as non-competes for healthcare providers [1].  
   - Remote workers have enhanced rights, including reimbursement for work-related expenses and equal access to benefits [4].  
   - Agricultural workers have specific overtime, break, and heat safety protections [2].

7. **State Employee Benefits**:  
   - Permanent and term-limited state employees are eligible for comprehensive benefits including medical, dental, vision, life insurance, disability, wellness programs, and flexible spending accounts [7][10].

   - The Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) enforces wage, hour, and benefit laws, including investigations, penalties, and public disclosure of violations [3][8].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA), which requires employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees with specific provisions for accrual, usage, carryover, and expanded leave rights during public health emergencies.

**Effective Dates and Employer Coverage**  
- Employers with 16 or more employees must provide earned paid sick leave starting January 1, 2021.  
- All employers, regardless of size, must comply starting January 1, 2022.  
- Until December 31, 2020, employers must comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which provides up to 80 hours of COVID-19-related sick leave. The HFWA does not require compliance with the FFCRA’s Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act.

**Employee Eligibility and Accrual**  
- Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire and may use it as soon as it is accrued.  
- Employees earn at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, unless the employer sets a higher limit.  
- Employers may front-load the full amount of paid sick leave at the start of the year to satisfy accrual requirements.  
- Exempt employees working less than 40 hours per week accrue leave based on their normal workweek hours.

**Permissible Reasons for Using Paid Sick Leave**  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for:  
- Their own mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Caring for a family member with a mental or physical illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Recovering from or addressing issues related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, victim services, counseling, relocation, or legal services.  
- Absences due to public health emergency orders closing the employee’s workplace or their child’s school or place of care.

**Usage and Notice Requirements**  
- Paid sick leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments.  
- Employers may loan paid sick leave to employees who have not yet accrued it.  
- Employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave.  
- Leave requests can be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any employer-accepted means.  
- Employers may adopt reasonable written notice policies for foreseeable leave but cannot deny leave for noncompliance. Employees should provide good faith notice and attempt to schedule leave to minimize business disruption.

**Carryover and Separation**  
- Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the next year, but employers may cap annual usage at 48 hours.  
- Employers are not required to pay out unused sick leave upon separation.  
- If an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate any unused accrued paid sick leave from prior employment.  
- Paid sick leave may be recovered as a remedy for retaliatory personnel actions that prevented its use.

**Paid Sick Leave During Public Health Emergencies**  
- Employees receive a one-time supplemental leave grant during a declared public health emergency (e.g., COVID-19), defined as a bioterrorism act, pandemic influenza, or epidemic with a declared disaster emergency.  
- Supplemental leave must be at least 80 hours for full-time employees or the equivalent of scheduled/average hours for part-time employees.  
- This leave covers:  
  - Self-isolation or care due to diagnosis or symptoms of the communicable illness causing the emergency.  
  - Seeking medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care related to the illness.  
  - Caring for family members who are self-isolating, symptomatic, diagnosed, or seeking preventive care.  
  - Situations where public officials determine the employee or family member’s presence would jeopardize others’ health.  
  - Caring for children or family members when childcare or schools are closed or unavailable due to the emergency.  
  - Employee’s inability to work due to a health condition increasing susceptibility to the illness.  
- Employers may count unused accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave.  
- Documentation cannot be required for this leave, and it may be used up to four weeks after the public health emergency ends.

**Recordkeeping and Enforcement**  
- Employers must retain records for two years documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and used.

- Violations may result in compensation to employees and civil fines up to $100 per willful retaliation violation.  
- Employees may file complaints with the Division or pursue civil action after notifying the employer and allowing 14 days for response.

**Anti-Retaliation Protections**  
- The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees for using paid sick leave and provides remedies for adverse actions.

**Notice to Employees**  
- Employers must notify employees in writing of their paid sick leave rights per Division rules.  
- Employers must post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A.

To further support compliance with the HFWA, many Colorado employers are turning to specialized legal compliance tools and software platforms designed to simplify the management of paid sick leave obligations. - Automated accrual calculations based on hours worked and employee classifications.

These trends reflect a broader shift toward holistic employee well-being and flexibility, influenced by the ongoing impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and changing workforce expectations.
